Perception of glycerol carbonate as green chemical: Synthesis and applications Swapna M. Gade Conceptualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Vitthal B. Tel:+91 9881263702 b Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai 400019, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga Mumbai 400019 India Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, 400019 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Glycerol carbonate (GC) is a prominent component in industrial practice and has a remarkable potential for the sophisticated applications. While GC has come into prominence due to the perceived overflow of glycerol (GLY) as a coproduct of biodiesel industry, its contemporary and future downstream applications are driving tremendous interest in recent years. This review comprises strategies for glycerol carbonate synthesis, properties and its applications. The conversion of GLY to GC via transesterification has appeared in consensus to be the most promising route. A detailed explanation of the effect of the catalysts and operating conditions on the GC yield to provide an updated understanding of the process are summarized. Future directions for GC production through catalytic transesterification are also discussed. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Glycerol Glycerol carbonate Biodiesel Green chemistry Biofuels Transesterification Catalysis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The rapidly growing world population and unsustainable consumptive industrial practices have put pressure not only on energy sectors, but also on the management of carbon footprint. The problems currently faced by nations, especially developing nations, is the prospect of depleting fuel reserves and dependence on foreign fuel, burgeoning greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and the looming cost of carbon footprint management. Unsurprisingly, a major focus of research is dedicated to establish alternative and renewable energy resources such as ultra-efficient solar cells, efficient wind turbine generators (WTG) including high-capacity marine WTGs, geothermal energy plants, biofuels etc. While technologies like WTGs, solar panels are established and are commercially viable, they face challenges of efficiency and unavailability depending on natural conditions. Consequently, as a cumulative phenomenon, the global energy sector is still almost completely dependent on fossil fuels. Bio-diesel is an alternative fuel with the potential to displace fossil fuel and its derivatives [1]. Bio-diesel is generated from plant biomass by the transesterification of methanol with vegetable oils and less commonly with recycled fat. The relatively low carbon footprint allows bio-diesel's utility as a green fuel, by virtue of its production, tunable sulfur content and lower pollution upon combustion on account of the methyl esters, primarily methyl oleate and linoleate. In face of rising fossil fuel costs, fuel transport logistics and to address the climate change agenda, North American and European interests are increasing bio-diesel production and India has developed its own agenda for bio-diesel manufacture from non-food utility plants such as Jatropha curcas [2]. GLY is a byproduct of the plant lipid-transesterification process via hydrolysis or alcoholysis of plant seed oil triglycerides. Much attention has been devoted to applying ‘green' catalytic processes to convert bio-renewable feedstock to commodity chemicals and cleaner biofuels. In this regard, a renewed focus on the processing of GLY to synthesize value-added products (Fig. 1 ) is now evident based on recent publications. GLY is determined to be generated at the rate of about 1 mol for every 3 mol of methyl esters synthesized and overall, approximately 10 wt% of the total product of bio-diesel [3]. In terms of byproduct-market value, the price of GLY has mildly fluctuated (Fig. 1) historically speaking and tended to diminish until the year 2020 [4]. Price trending for the decade starting 2008 and extending to virtually the end of 2020 suggest a strong price control around USD 1000/ton glycerol. However, this pricing was disturbed by the supply-chain disruption in the year 2021 causing GLY price to sharply spike up almost three-fold to 2650 US $/ton in the quarter ending in December 2021. On the other hand, global interest in GLY and GC has risen virtually exponentially, as evident in a study of publications featuring GC over the last sixty years (Fig. 2 ). The rising awareness of GC as a multi-functional compound has been exploited to improve a variety of industrial reactions. To make bio-diesel manufacture commercially viable, it is essential to market and utilize GLY [1]. Utilization of GLY for the synthesis of value-added chemicals is of commercial and industrial importance, not only because GLY can be formed in large amounts, but also because GLY is a nontoxic, edible, bio-sustainable and biodegradable [6,7]. In this respect, ideal reaction-catalysis provides a plausible approach to green chemical technology in the activation and utilization of GLY. Significant work on the development of catalysts has been executed thus far and continues to be carried out. Amongst the products prepared from GLY, GC is considered a small volume chemical with emerging applications. The aim of this review is to assess contemporary information available on the development of improved catalysts for the synthesis of GC (Scheme 3-7) from GLY and possibly deduce a commercially viable route that will lead the way towards greater utilization of glycerol and biodiesel. The purity of biodiesel-glycerol is a major issue, primarily due to unspent catalyst (mostly homogeneous), water, salts and esters formed during the biodiesel process [8]. Consequently, valorization and purification of GLY has generated increasing interest amongst researchers within the last couple of decades. Due to the dramatic growth of biodiesel industry, valorization of GLY has seemingly become the need of the hour [1,3,9]. Synthesis of GC from GLY performed using several direct and indirect carbonylative reagents like, phosgene (COCl2), CO/O2, CO2, solid bases as CO sources like KHCO3/K2CO3 and transesterification using cyclic/acyclic carbonates and urea (Scheme 1 ). Amongst the all, transesterification of GLY with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is the most efficient and sustainable pathway because it generates methanol as only sole by-product which have low boiling point and easy to separate from reaction mixture. Additionally, generated methanol can be reused for the synthesis of DMC from carbon dioxide (CO2). While, diols formed using the cyclic carbonates and ammonia from urea are although attractive approach but difficult to separate. Other conventional methods including phosgene and CO/O2 are difficult to handle due to use of toxic starting material. Range of homogeneous and heterogeneous including acid, basic and acid-base (bifunctional) catalysts have been developed for the all the methods. Although, heterogeneous catalysts are always preferred over homogeneous and enzyme due to potential reusability, easy recovery and high catalytic activity in a shorter reaction time. Additionally, heterogeneous catalysts are easily adaptable for the process intensification process with the use of suitable reactor for product separation strategies and used to generate large scale production and commercialization for example GC synthesis from GLY, jacketed glass reactors, stainless steel autoclave reactors, continuous reactors and microwave reactors systems have been used [10,11]. In this review, discusses the recent catalytic methods used for the synthesis of GC from GLY. Special emphasis is given to the catalytic transesterification of DMC with GLY to GC with various reaction parameters are emphasized in terms of activity. An exhaustive summary of GC-associated work is outside the scope of this document, consequently a few publications reporting minor incremental improvements or commentary have been left out. Lastly, probable research gaps for future additional studies have been suggested. This review summarizes important aspects for GC synthesis which include importance of selection of proper catalyst, selection of reactor for reaction, application of the commercially-valuable GC, physical as well as chemical characteristics of the compounds. 2 Physical properties and applications of glycerol carbonate (GC) 2.1 Reactivity of GC GC has both nucleophilic and electrophilic sites which enables broad reactivity due to the presence of a primary hydroxyl group and a 2-oxo-1,3-dioxolane (ODO) group respectively (Scheme 2 ) [12,13]. Presence of functional groups like hydroxyl, carbonyl and CO bonds, it can react with other functional groups. Reaction schemes depicting wide spectrum reactions of GC are discussed below in detail. 2.1.1 Esterification In a typified manner, GC reacts with carboxylic acid to form an ester linkage (Scheme 3 ). Jana et al. investigated the synthesis of cyclic carbonate methacrylate monomer using coupling reagents such as N, N′-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC) and 4-dimethylaminopyridine. The described yield after purification was about 67% [14]. A more recent study by Morales-Cerrada et al. shows the utility of glycerol carbonate methacrylate in formation of co-monomers which are useful in synthesizing methacrylates with greater strength, transparency and ease of synthesis. Methacrylates form a class of polymers which are particularly desirable as coatings for glass and metal on account of their strength and aesthetic properties [15]. 2.1.2 Reactions with isocyanate Ochiaiet et al. [16] investigated the synthesis of 2-methacrylic acid2-(2-oxo-[1,3]dioxolan-4 ylmethoxycarbonylamino) ethyl ester (CUMA) by a reaction between GC and 2-methacryloyloxyethyl isocyanate in the presence of di-n-butyltindilaurate and dichloromethane as a solvent (Scheme 4 ). CUMA is used as a co-polymer to increase the flexibility and stability, compared to the brittleness of normal cyclic carbonates-polymers. 2.1.3 Tosylation reaction In order to improve selectivity and reactivity, the primary hydroxyl of GC can be activated by simple tosylation reaction (Scheme 5 ). Olivero et al. obtained 3-O-tosyl glycerol 1,2‑carbonate by reacting GC with p-toluenesulfonyl chloride under the influence of triethylamine [14]. Tosylated species have significant utility in synthesis of sulfanylmethyl-dioxolan-2-ones using benign AlO3 based catalysts, as reviewed by Rollin et al. [17]. 2.1.4 Acid halide The hydroxyl group of GC reacts with acid dual-halide to form ester linkage to a halide‑carbon. Palaskar et al. reported the synthesis of 2-oxo-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl-(methyl-2-bromo-2-methylpropanoate)(ODOMBMP) by the reaction of GC with 2-bromoisobutyrylbromide in the presence of triethylamine (Scheme 6 ) [18]. 2.2 Broader applications of glycerol carbonate Owing to its chemical reactivity, GC has several contemporary practical applications and newer utilities continue to emerge [19]. A thematic overview is presented in the Fig. 3 and discussed below. GC has potential applications as a novel component of gas-separation liquid-phase membranes, as a solvent for several types of materials and a component in coatings, paints and detergents, by virtue of its properties like metal-adhesiveness and resistance to oxidation, hydrolysis and pressure [20]. As newer applications emerge, researchers are looking at better methods of synthesis for these industrially relevant products [21]. Transesterification of GLY to GC has appeared in consensus as the most promising route for GC synthesis. 2.2.1 Solvent As a solvent, GC has both ionizing and dissociating abilities, very similar to water. It is consequently a very effective solvent for processes like pretreatment of sugarcane-bagasse. Due to presence of the hydroxyl group in GC, higher glucose yield is possible, on account of which more significant biomass delignification and defibrillation outcomes are obtained. Solvent pretreatment of the sugarcane-macerate reduced bagasse particles to a large extent [22]. High-boiling carbonates are useful solvents for reactions under vacuum conditions at higher temperatures. They are obtainable from GC with carboxylic acid chlorides (Scheme 7 ). High boiling carbonates are very viscous at room temperature. GC as a solvent can be applied in the telomerization of butadiene with carbon dioxide to form δ-lactones, which are valuable intermediates for a large variety of reactions. 2.2.2 Gas separation liquid membrane GC has also been investigated for its putative role as a ‘physical’ separation-solvent for advanced segregation of CO2 from a complex mixture of carbon dioxide and nitrogen [24]. An exploration of the so-called GC-immobilized liquid membrane (ILM) yielded promising results; Kovvali et al., reported separation factors α CO2/N2 in the range of 80–100. It is interesting to note the enhanced CO2 permeability (Q CO2 ) of the ILM in presence of increased moisture content virtually triples in value. Doping the ILM with facilitators improved CO2 fixing in low feed-partial pressures. Modification of the ILM to be used as ultra-thin membranes or as hollow/porous fibers is predicted to improve its performance further [24]. 2.2.3 Lithium batteries An important contemporary application of GC has been explored by Wang et al. on synthesis of organosilicon functionalized glycerol carbonates have considerable potential as electrolyte solvent/additive in lithium-ion batteries [25]. They have reported that di-siloxane functionalized glycerol carbonate acts as an efficient electrolyte additive to improve the wetting property on the separator in Li/LiCoO2 cells. Wang et al. claims superiority of GC over ethylene and propylene carbonates due to a characteristic feature of GC, like, its low vapor pressure and low flammability than propylene carbonate and ethylene carbonate [25]. Thus, GC has an extensive future potential window if exploited in lithium-ion cells. Additionally, GC is recognized to form oligomers under appropriate conditions and can form electrode passivation layers that increase cell longevity. 2.2.4 Application for preparation of polymers Camara et al. reported free radical polymerization of (2-oxo-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl) methyl methacrylate (glycerin carbonate methacrylate, GCMA) [26]. The study justifies the use of carbonation as the preferred method of synthesis over transesterification, since the latter yields are by-products. The high concentration (up to 2 M) of GCMA drives the cross-linking of substrates; polymers bearing cyclic carbonate functional groups can be used for crosslinking reactions to form urethane-linkages without the use of toxic isocynates. It is interesting to note the superior reactivity of GCMA (>4-fold) compared to methyl methacrylate. GCMA is also instrumental in the synthesis of high-molecular-weight multifunctional glycerol polyhydroxyurethanes (PHUs) polymer [27]. As mentioned earlier, GCMA is utilized in formation of co-monomers which are useful in synthesizing methacrylates for applications in metal and glass coatings [15]. 2.2.5 Additives in nail paints Due to plasticizing properties of GC, it is used in colorless nail polish formulation. The thin film of nail polish showed the high plasticizing effect in the direction of nitrocellulose containing films. It was due to hydrogen bond connections amongst GC and nitrocellulose. Due to the presence of GC the ingredients of the plasticizer in the preparation were reduced. In light of the concept of the green chemistry and safer synthesis, GC can be use in nail polish formulation [28]. 2.2.6 Alkylating agent for the synthesis of β-aryloxy alcohols In the synthesis of several drugs, due to the basic structure of GC it can be use in selective synthesis of cyclic ethers. It is possible because of its unique characteristic of pendent -OH present on GC structure. The pendent−OH allows creating additional cyclic carbonate, which characterizes the sole and highly active intermediate for the ring closure reaction, which forms 2-hydroxymethyl-1,4-benzodioxane [20]. Due to the importance of β-aryloxy alcohols, there has been a revival in the exploration of fresh applications of the multiutility compound GC, however a surprisingly small impact has been noted in publications on GC as an alkylating agent for phenolic substrates. This presents a particularly interesting area of expansion as GC enjoys a useful position in alkylating compounds such as catechol resulting in the very useful intermediate 2-hydroxymethyl-1,4-benzodioxane. 2.3 Physical properties of glycerol and glycerol carbonate Both GLY and GC are colorless and slightly viscous liquids. GC has a wide liquid-state temperature range, low melting point (−69 °C) and high boiling point (353.9 °C) which is an unusual property for its application as a solvent (Table 1 ) [14]. In terms of flammability, GC exhibits flash point (FP) around 190 °C. While liquids with low FP pose operational danger, the higher FP for GC thus presents a safer alternative [12,29]. GC has a dielectric constant closer to water hence it can be used as an excellent solvent for various organic reactions [14,30]. The toxicity of cyclic alkylene carbonates is relatively low, based on oral and dermal acute toxicity testing. When injected through the skin, it is converted metabolically into a corresponding glycol and CO2. GC gets converted into GLY and CO2, which in physiological concentrations have little to no toxicity, since these are present endogenously as well. It is interesting to note that no R-phrase is mentioned in the official MSDS documents supplied for GC. 3 Synthetic methods 3.1 Transesterification of GLY with DMC Transesterification of GLY using DMC is the most capable and cautiously feasible pathway for GC synthesis because of non-hazardous nature of DMC and the only side product is methanol [31]. Though it is a safer route for GC synthesis, it needs high threshold energy for bond breaking during the transesterification reaction. This reaction is tricky so, the catalyst choice is very important for selective and faster production of GC. Therefore, the lower activation energy catalyst should be fed in the reaction. The catalytic production of GC with DMC has been discovered as a green method as it eases the energy necessities during GLY conversion selectivity and yield increases to the chosen products as well. Transesterification of GLY and DMC has been well established area using various homogeneous catalysts such as ionic liquids [32]. metal complexes of tin [33] soluble metal salts like carbonates, bicarbonates and sulphates of alkali and alkaline earth metals [34]. Heterogeneous catalysts have also been used extensively including metal oxides, mixed metal oxides [35–37], hydrotalcites [38], supported hydrotalcites [39,40], various clays [41], ion exchange resins [42], zeolites [14,43], perovskite-based mixed metal oxide nanoparticles [44] etc. The detailed literature on the synthesis of GC from GLY and DMC, with noteworthy reports are discussed below in Table 2 . The stoichiometric reaction involved in the transesterification of DMC with GLY is presented in the Scheme 8 . Rockiki et al. [45] reported selective synthesis of GC by the transesterification of GLY with DMC using K2CO3 as a base catalyst under mild reaction conditions. With the projected increase in bio-diesel production, GLY will be available in larger quantity. With this expectation, research work on valorization of GLY has gained momentum, as can be seen from the number of reports on GC synthesis in recent years [45]. Synthesis of GC from GLY with DMC as a carbonate source results in the formation of methanol as a by-product. DMC and by-product methanol both are volatile and hence can be removed from the reaction mixture. Also, methanol formed as a by-product can be converted to DMC easily by oxidative carbonylation on a commercial scale (Enichem process) [46]. Thus transesterification of GLY with DMC has a potential to give an atom-efficient process. Another dialkyl carbonate used for the transesterification reaction is diethyl carbonate. Also, GC is important products with many potential applications and their ways of synthesis from GLY are presented in the following section. It is noteworthy to mention here that, basic catalysts are preferred for the typical transesterification reaction, a reaction which proceeds via activation by proton abstraction to make the reactive intermediate [47–49]. For effective commercialization of the GC, the process requires a stable catalyst under the defined reaction conditions used for the GC synthesis. Homogeneous catalysts have catalyst recovery challenges because of the polarity of the compounds used. In case of heterogeneous catalysts, it is generally possible to separate out the catalyst after each reaction. Several groups are actively working on multiple aspects of the transesterification reaction of GLY with DMC. A few of these findings are discussed below, especially the reports with the interesting, relevant results. Ochoa-Gómez et al. [50] have investigated transesterification of GLY and DMC in detail. They have screened homogeneous as well as heterogeneous basic catalysts like, CaO, CaCO3, MgO, Amberlyst A26 (OH form) and Amberjet 4400 [OH form] and acidic catalysts H2SO4, p-toluenesulfonic acid, Amberlyst 131 Wet and Amberlyst 39 Wet for the reaction. It was found that basic catalysts are far superior to acidic catalysts for GC synthesis. Thus, with H2SO4 as catalyst 94.5% conversion of GLY with 50% yield of GC was obtained at 75 °C in 24 h. On the other hand, the reaction proceeded smoothly with homogeneous as well as heterogeneous base catalysts. It was observed that activity increased dramatically with increase in temperature beyond 70 °C with base catalysts. Best results (100% conversion of GLY with >95% yield of GC) were achieved with 6 mol% CaO as catalyst with 100% conversion and ∼ 95% GC yield at 95 °C in 1.5 h reaction time. Proposed the mechanism (Scheme 9 ) with the formation of glyceride from GLY by abstraction of “H” by base as the first step of reaction. The glyceride formed attacks on the carbonyl carbon of DMC forming glyceryl methyl carbonate (GMC), which further undergoes a similar reaction cycle and leads to the formation of GC as the final product. Munshi et al. [61] have investigated various amines and best results were obtained with amidines like 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene(DBU)and1,5-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]non-5-ene (DBN). Under optimized conditions (GLY:DMC mole ratio: 1:3, temperature 100 °C, reaction time: 2 h) 98% conversion of GLY with 96% selectivity to GC was obtained with DBU as the catalyst. At a catalyst loading of 0.001 mol% very high turnover number (TON, 9408, GC formed) was reported for the first time. The reaction mechanism was investigated with the help of 1H, 13C and 15N NMR analysis and DFT calculations. Granados-Reyes et al. [60] have investigated CaAl layered double hydroxides as catalysts for GC synthesis. CaAl-LDHs were prepared by precipitation method using nitrate or chloride salts with and without ultrasound, and aged hydrothermally in autoclave or by refluxing with and without microwave irradiation method. All the prepared catalysts were active, and complete conversion of GLY with GC selectivity in a range 65–75% was observed in 24 h. Hervert et al. [66] have reported room temperature synthesis of GC using N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) as catalysts (Scheme 10 I, II). Thus >95% yield of GC was obtained in 20 min using 109 mmol GLY (GLY:DMC molar ratio:: 1:3.5) at room temperature with 4 mol% of NHC (II) as the catalyst. Authors have proposed the possible reaction mechanism for the synthesis of GC using NHC as a catalyst (Scheme 10). This is the first report on the synthesis of GC with high yield at room temperature using NHC as a catalyst. The attack by NHC (A) on the carbonyl of DMC leads to the formation of intermediate (B). GLY acts as a nucleophile and reacts with the intermediate (B) to form (C) with elimination of methanol. Intramolecular attack of the hydroxyl on carbonyl carbon leads to the formation of GC product with regeneration of the NHC (A). Recent results with ionic liquids (ILs) and NHC carbenes as catalysts clearly showed that organo-catalysts are efficient for the selective synthesis of GC. Also, it is noteworthy that there are limited reports on the use of organo-catalysts for this reaction. Ochoa-Gómez et al. [68] have investigated the transesterification of GLY and DMC using triethylamine (TEA) as a simple separable homogeneous catalyst. According to authors, 99% GLY conversion was achieved with 90–98% yield of GC at 80 °C temperature using 1:3 M ratio of GLY:DMC and 10 mol% catalyst loading. Optimization of reaction conditions was carried out and activity was found to increase dramatically with increase in reaction temperature. Similarly, transesterification of GC to glycerol dicarbonate (GDC) was also observed at TEA:GLY ratio of 0.3 reducing overall selectivity to GC. Selective extraction of GC was carried out with methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK, MIBK/reaction mixture mass ratio of 1.6) at room temperature. Three extraction steps were necessary to achieve almost complete extraction of GC with purity higher than 98%. Algoufi et al. [69] have carried out transesterification of GLY with DMC using K-zeolite prepared by hydrothermal treatment from fly ash as the catalyst. Complete conversion of GLY with 96% selectivity to GC was obtained at 75 °C with 3:1 ratio of DMC:GLY and catalyst loading of 4 wt% in 2 h. The catalyst was recycled four times, retaining high activity and selectivity. In this respective study, high GC yield to noticeably high surface basicity of the catalysts and the reactions were carried out under mild conditions. ‘Red mud’ (RM) as a catalyst has been reportedly prepared from industrial waste. Ladle furnace slag from steel industries has been used to synthesize GC [86]. RM contains catalytically active elements Fe, Al, Ti, Si, Ca, and Na in different minerals forms, which makes it appropriate for usage as a catalyst for numerous processes. Basic strength and catalyst basicity have noteworthy effects on the transesterification reaction [50]. For the transesterification of GLY to produce GC, catalysts with strong basic sites and moderate basic strength are highly desirable [86] Okoye et al. proposed a reaction mechanism (Scheme 11 ) that glyceroxide anion (C3H7O3 −) basic site of the catalyst activating glycerol whereas on RM catalyst Lewis acid sites (AlO2 −) are present which makes the carbonyl carbon of DMC highly positive by managing to its carbonyl oxygen. Further, on nucleophilic attack, methyl glyceryl carbonate gets formed along with methoxide anion. That anion combines with H+ ion on base abstraction to form methanol. Next, the basic site of the catalyst scavenges the additional H+ ion from the secondary -OH group of GLY, leaving behind an O− group in GLY. Further, GLY makes a second nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl carbon and finally, undergoes a cyclization reaction to produce GC by eliminating a methanol group. Due to the presence of highly active and strong basic sites of NaAlO2 and Ca2SiO4 on the RM catalyst, significant activity under mild reaction conditions were observed within 90 min of reaction time. However, the stability of the catalyst after three recycling uses was a major issue. There are limited reports on the use of ILs as catalysts for this reaction. Naik et al. [33] have carried out the synthesis of GC from GLY and DMC with imidazolium-2-carboxylates IL as a catalyst. GLY rapidly reacts with 3.2 equivalents of DMC in the presence of 5 mol% of IL catalyst (BMIM-2-CO2), to afford quantitative GC yield within 30 min at 75 °C (Scheme 12 ). Chiappe and Rajamani [96] have investigated dicyanamide-based ILs as catalysts. Complete conversion of GLY with selective formation of GC was observed with [Mor1,4][N(CN)2] (17 mol% w. r. t GLY) in 13 h at 120 °C. The ILs was recycled 4 times, retaining high selectivity to GC. However, high catalyst loading, higher reaction temperature and longer reaction time were necessary to achieve the good results reported. Several hydrotalcites (Mg/Al [56], Mg/La [67], Ca/Al [60]) and hydrotalcite derived metal oxides (Zn/La [63], Ca/La [42]) have been used as catalyst for GC synthesis. Takagaki et al. [56] have investigated the reaction using Mg/Al hydrotalcite with different ratios of Mg:Al as catalyst. GC yield of 99% was obtained with 5 wt% of Mg/Al (5:1) hydrotalcite with GLY:DMC molar ratio of 1:5, DMF as solvent for 2 h at 100 °C. Interestingly, it was observed that the activity of calcined hydrotalcite was very poor compared to uncalcined catalyst. The catalyst was recycled three times with high activity. Dahdah et al. have reported Mg/Al hydrotalcite basicity can be enhance by rehydration process which could be helpful for GC synthesis [97]. Chen et al. has reported used diaper-derived heterogeneous magnetic catalyst for synthesis of transesterification reaction [78,98]. To solve the tedious procedure of developing magnetic heterogeneous catalyst (MHC), Chen and his co-workers have developed simple and low-cost method to prepare MHC for the synthesis of GC from GLY and DMC at mild reaction conditions (Table 3 ). Used diaper waste is one of the contents in municipal wastes and prepared from non-biodegradable polymer ingredients, super absorbent resin (sodium polyacrylate) and non-woven polypropylene [71,79]. This may present an opportunity to combine the noble goals of removing non-biodegradable polymers and valorization to form GC. Hydroxypropyl-tripentylammonium hydroxide [HPTPA]OH as an ionic liquid (IL) catalyst showed the best activity for the reaction with DMC and GLY for GC synthesis. A reaction mechanism was proposed for the transesterification of DMC with GLY catalyzed by [HPTPA]OH IL, depicted below (Scheme 13 ). This ILs showed excellent recyclability up to three cycles [80]. Initially, the primary OH bond of GLY and CO bond of DMC can be acted upon by the hydroxyl functional group of the cation and the hydroxyl group of the anion originating from [HPTPA]OH, correspondingly, active state of DMC and GLY with the formation of (HO⋯H) hydrogen bond and (O-H…O) hydrogen bond. After that, activated GLY can execute a nucleophilic attack to the carbonyl carbon atom of DMC to form an intermediate that is methyl glyceryl carbonate with elimination of methanol. Afterward, the secondary OH bond of GLY is also activated by the OH− anion of the [HPTPA]OH through the creation of the (HO⋯H) hydrogen bond, at the same time the oxygen atom builds an intramolecular nucleophilic attack on carbonyl carbon atom to form GC with a loss of second molecule of methanol. The presence of strong basic site (OH−) and mild acidic site (OH) on IL are key active centers. Base activate the hydroxyl functionality of GLY while the carbonyl group of DMC activated by hydroxyl group by hydrogen bond donor (HBD) which assist the formation of GC with elimination of methanol. A comparable study was done by Wang et al., who reported functionalized 2,2,2 trifluoroehanol with 1,1,3,3 tetramethylguanidine catalyst with turnover frequency 1754 h−1. In the study, 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol ion is reported as the strongest Brønsted base acceptor that demonstrates H-bond basicity. Within 30 min of reaction time, GLY showed 92% conversion with 95.5% GC selectivity due to the collaborative effect of cation-anion [89]. According to the recent requirement and valorization of GLY, we may well have to investigate the value-added product formation in depth. Transesterification of GLY with DMC to synthesize GC is a well-known reaction pathway to valorize excess and possibly waste GLY. To improve the production of the relatively inexpensive GC which is routinely inhibited due to reaction mass-transfer issues of GLY and DMC. The conceivable requirement here is to establish a highly stable catalyst for continuous flow systems or for batch reactor system. Separation of catalyst, product-reactant-catalyst system for a viable separation method has to be developed. A review on trends in azeotrope separation strategies, catalytic conversion of biodiesel-derived GLY and reactor systems by Okoye et al. studied a variety of recent reports on reactor systems and CH3OH-DMC azeotrope parting tactics explored in GC synthesis from biodiesel-derived GLY [99]. Okoye et al. have further studied thermocatalytic paths and reactor strategies for valorization of biodiesel-derived glycerol to fuels [100]. A positive effect of calcination temperature on structural development, basicity and activity of oil palm empty-fruit (OPF) derived catalyst for GC synthesis was studied. OPF was calcined at different temperatures which produced varying results in an autoclave reactor system, presumably due to change in basic strength of the OPF catalyst. The cumulative change in GLY from 72.45% to 97%, when the calcination temperature was amplified from 300 to 500 °C was obtained, extolling the profile-raising properties of catalyst basicity (from 1.84 to 3.40 mmol/g) by calcination. 3.2 GC synthesis by carbonylation with CO Alternatively, oxidative carbonylation of GLY provides a highly efficient approach for the synthesis of GC (Scheme 14 ) with the formation of water as by-product. Important catalytic methods have been summarized in Table 3. The process is attractive because of the relatively easy availability of CO and high atom economy (87%) [101]. The reaction is catalyzed by homogeneous catalysts including PdCl2(phen)/KI (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) [101], Wacker-type catalyst system, Pd(OAc)2/Mn(acac)3/KBr [107] and PdI2/KI [108]. With CuI as co-catalyst, this catalyst system exhibited activity comparable to its homogeneous counterpart and moreover, demonstrated the capability of being reused upto five times without significant decrease in activity. Oxidative carbonylation is an atom efficient route for GC synthesis, and water is primarily formed as the by-product. However, explosion hazards associated with the use of CO/O2 mixture is the major drawback of this route. Hence, limited reports are available on this route. Mizuno et al. have developed a Pd based catalyst system for carbonylation of GLY with CO and used sulfur or selenium as hydrogen acceptors instead of oxygen [105]. The typical reaction conditions used for the reaction are (Temperature: 80 °C, Pressure: 2 MPa Time: 5 h). Though, >90% GLY conversion with high selectivity to GC (83%–84%) was obtained, stoichiometric requirement of selenium or sulfur and formation of selenium hydride or H-S-S-H in stoichiometric quantity are major drawbacks of this route. Additionally, re-oxidation of selenium hydride or H-S-S-H is necessary in this reaction. There are limited reports on this route because of the explosion hazards associated with the use of CO/O2 mixture as well; toxicity of CO and the inherent difficulty to handle it safely both at laboratory and industrial scales [54]. 3.3 Synthesis by carboxylation with CO2 There are several reports on the synthesis of GC by carbonylation of GLY with or CO2 [14,101–103]. However, carboxylation of GLY with CO2 is the most atom-efficient and safe route; in this process two ‘waste’ by-products are converted into a value added chemical (Scheme). From an economical point of view, this reaction is advantageous as it simultaneously tackles two waste products, of which CO2 is considered a primary threat in the global warming crisis [102]. Furthermore, both compounds are produced in both biological and industrial scenarios (gross CO2 emission) which lend themselves to commercial viability. The direct synthesis of GC by the reaction of GLY with CO2 is highly desirable, although a challenging reaction (Scheme 15 ). There are few reports on this reaction using homogeneous/heterogeneous catalysts (Table 4 ). GC synthesis from CO2 and GLY has been mostly investigated using tin based catalysts such as di(n-butyl)tin dimethoxide [109], di(n-butyl)tin oxide and tin dimethoxide [110]. Under the investigated reaction conditions (50 bar CO2 pressure, 180 °C) tin dimethoxide led only to traces of GC. However, di(n-butyl)tin dimethoxide with molecular sieves (for the removal of water formed during the reaction) led to a GLY conversion of maximum 7% at a pressure of 5 MPa, temperature of 180 °C in 15 h and without any solvent. Ezhova et al. observed trace amount of GC with RhCl3 + PPh3 + KI as a catalyst and methanol as a solvent (5 MPa CO2 pressure at 140 °C) [111]. The reason for the lower yield of GC were the thermodynamic equilibrium and moisture sensitivity of the employed catalysts. Consequently, rather poor yields are reported in the literature and limited reports are available on this reaction. 3.4 GC synthesis by using GLY and urea The reaction of GLY and urea provides an atom efficient route for the synthesis of GC, since ammonia produced in the reaction can be easily converted to urea (Scheme 16 ). Important catalytic methods for the synthesis of GC form GLY using urea as carbonyl source have been summarized in Table 5 . Synthesis of GC from urea and glycerol is an equilibrium controlled reaction and efficient removal of ammonia is necessary to improve yield of GC and also to avoid formation of by-products like Glycerol urethane, 5-(hydroxymethyl)oxazolidin-2-one, (2-oxo-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl)methyl carbamate [112]. For this reason the reaction is carried out under reduced pressure or nitrogen bubbling. Simple metal salts have been used as catalysts for the synthesis of GC from urea and glycerol [116,122,128]. The reaction in this case was carried out in a temperature range of 120–150 °C under reduced pressure. The yield of GC obtained was in a range of 55 to 90%. Yoo and Mouloungui et al. [129] used zinc-based catalysts like p-toluene sulphonic acid zinc salt, zinc sulphate and cation exchange resin with zinc cation for the synthesis of GC from GLY and urea. The reaction was investigated at an operating temperature range of 140–150 °C under reduced pressure and the best results (85% yield of GC in 1.25 h reaction time) were obtained using p-toluene sulphonic acid and zinc salt as the catalyst. GC has been synthesized from urea with various heterogeneous catalysts such as ZnO, Zn based mixed metal oxides derived from hydrotalcite, Sn-Beta [112], gamma‑zirconium phosphate [130], SnW mixed metaloxides [120], La2O3 [114], Co3O4/ZnO [117], Au/Fe2O3 [115], Sm0.6TPA [121], Zn1TPA [118], ZnSn(OH)6 [127], Zn-exchanged zeolites [131], Zn/MCM-41 [123], and quaternary ammonium ion exchanged montmorillonite [132]. Amongst them, the zinc based catalysts have shown a promising activity because of their Lewis acidic nature. Wang et al. [122] have reported the synthesis of GC using various soluble lanthanum compounds as catalysts. Optimum results (95.4% conversion of GLY with 99.9% selectivity to GC) were obtained using LaCl3 as the catalyst at 150 °C (1 kPa pressure) with 1 mmol catalyst loading in 3 h. High activity and selectivity to GC was attributed to soluble nature of LaCl3. It was observed that the catalyst precipitated after the reaction as yellow complex and was found to be La(NH3)3Cl3 based on detailed characterization. Also, Li/NaY Zeolite, La, Ce based catalysts has been known for transesterification reaction [133–135]. Manjunathan et al. [127] have used ZnSn mixed metal oxide as highly active and selective catalyst for the synthesis of GC from urea and GLY with nitrogen bubbling. Best results (96% conversion of GLY with 99.6% selectivity to GC) was obtained with ZnSn mixed metal oxide catalyst prepared using co-precipitation method with ZnSn molar ratio of 2:1 and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h. The catalyst was recycled for four times with marginal drop in GLY conversion. Kondawar et al. [123] have investigated GC synthesis using Zn/MCM-41 catalyst. The catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method and 75% conversion of glycerol, with 99% selectivity to GC was observed under optimized reaction conditions. Catalyst was recycled three times without a significant drop in the activity and without leaching of Zn. From the literature reviewed it appears that, synthesis of GC from urea and GLY, is a promising route for future application point of view. Urea is available at a cheaper price, and ammonia formed as the by-product in this reaction can be easily reconverted to the urea. However, ammonia formed is in very insignificant quantity compared to capacities of the urea plant and hence one possible way would be to combine a chemical unit producing GC from urea with other chemical units consuming the produced ammonia. 3.5 GC synthesis by transesterification of GLY with alkylene carbonates Transesterification of organic carbonates (Dialkyl carbonates: dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) or cyclic carbonates; ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC) with GLY is a popular route for the synthesis of GC (Scheme 17 ). This route generates GC and alcohol/diol as by-products (Table 6 ). The reaction is catalyzed by immobilized ionic liquid on MCM-41, which is demonstrated to give high activity, which increases further upon increase in temperature and reaction time [136]. The authors further evaluated the recycle-competency of the catalyst which was reported to be three, in other words, the catalyst could be recycled twice without appreciable loss of activity. The catalyst, therefore holds some value due to its activity and ability to be recycled, however the limited cycles may be a limitation on the industrial scale. Initial studies on the synthesis of GC from organic carbonates were carried out mostly using EC or PC [137]. The catalysts used include alkali metal salts like hydroxides, carbonates, bicarbonates, phosphates and borates, anionic, bicarbonated or hydroxylated macroporous resin, or a three-dimensional X- or Y-type zeolites as catalysts [137]. The reaction was carried out in a temperature range of 80–170 °C and GC yield in a range of 88–98% was obtained. However, in these reactions high boiling by-product like ethylene glycol or propylene glycol is obtained [138]. GC also being high boiling compound; separation and purification of GC is difficult. Also, cyclic carbonates are costly and hence this route is not attractive for future developments. 3.6 Phosgenation route for GC synthesis Conventionally GC is synthesized by the reaction of phosgene with glycerol as shown in the Scheme 18 [103,139]. However, the toxicity of phosgene and generation of salts in stoichiometric quantity are major problems with this conventional method, as discussed earlier. Because of the toxicity of phosgene, significant amount of work is being carried out on the improvement of safer routes for synthesis of GC. Various routes developed for GC synthesis include direct or indirect synthesis routes namely, carbonylation with CO and CO2, glycerolysis of urea and transesterification with organic carbonates [14,92,102,140]. 4 Conclusion and future outlook The useful physical and chemical properties of GC make it an industrial platform molecule with applications in pharmaceutical, fine chemicals and polymer industry, amongst others. Amongst the four routes discussed, catalytic transesterification of dialkyl carbonate with GLY is one of the most attractive and sustainable way. As DMC has emerged as a ‘green reagent’ generates methanol as a by-product, can easily separate from GC by distillation and methanol can be reused to synthesis the DMC from CO2 as C1 source. This study showed that, several heterogeneous catalysts demonstrated comparable activity to homogeneous with acidic and basic sites. In homogeneous, catalyst and product separation make the reaction tedious for large scale. Basic catalysts are routinely considered for the transesterification reaction. Tunable basicity is also an option for selection of catalysts. Use of waste-derived catalysts which has the requisite basic strength to permit a GC transesterification reaction also reported. A green-scoped strategy can make carboxylation of GLY a commercially viable process for GC production. Overall, the consensus on utilization of waste or byproduct glycerol appears commercially viable, especially over many years of operation to offset processing plant costs. The source of glycerol would need to be renewable or waste-derived in nature to truly diminish the costs of production and to deliver a value-added product. However, reaction is sensitive to moisture, conversion is very low and equilibrium is controlled. Water removal is a must to advance the conversion of glycerol. Although some bio-catalyzed reactions reported, they are not feasible because of its inherent protein instability and high cost of enzymes. Heterogeneous acid catalyzed reaction showed less activity as compared with base. Highly basic catalysts lead to the formation of glycidol which is not a desired product in the endeavour of producing GC. Hence, reaction parameters, selection of catalysts especially basic will be key. Large-scale production of glycerol carbonate at an economical route may require proper reactor configuration. Unfortunately, relatively limited information is available on this aspect, and it is required to be addressed to assess the impact of change in the reactor design. Development of improved catalysts for these routes is therefore highly desirable and is expected to contribute to an increase in glycerol valorization and promote the commercial acceptance of glycerol carbonate. • Reaction parameters, selection of appropriate class of catalysts with basic and acidic sites will play crucial role and hence, design of catalyst with tunable basicity, acidity and bifunctional nature will be highly desirable. • Design of catalysts with earth abundant material or waste-derived catalysts which has the requisite basic strength to permit a GC transesterification reaction are necessary. • Especially, heterogeneous catalysts derived from left-over materials with tailored or tunable basic strength, will be the finest catalyst for GLY transesterification. • Transesterification of glycerol using alkyl carbonates and glycerolysis of urea, are atom efficient routes. Progress to improve catalysts selection and reactor choice are highly desirable. • Generally, conventional reaction conditions (thermal) are practiced, use of sustainable process like photo or electrocatalysis will be beneficial. • Although, very few of biocatalysts are tested, there is huge scope for the sustainable production of GC with enzyme catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol carbonate (GC) is a prominent component in industrial practice and has a remarkable potential for the sophisticated applications. While GC has come into prominence due to the perceived overflow of glycerol (GLY) as a coproduct of biodiesel industry, its contemporary and future downstream applications are driving tremendous interest in recent years. This review comprises strategies for glycerol carbonate synthesis, properties and its applications. The conversion of GLY to GC via transesterification has appeared in consensus to be the most promising route. A detailed explanation of the effect of the catalysts and operating conditions on the GC yield to provide an updated understanding of the process are summarized. Future directions for GC production through catalytic transesterification are also discussed.
